app.name: Ecosystems
app.info:
Sprout Labs - Learning Reimagined!

Ecosystems HD is a visually engaging and fun exploration of the major biomes of the Earth.

Ever wondered why plants and animals have specific adaptations. Why do plants in the rainforest have drip tip leaves? Why do conifers have needle leaves? Why does the jackrabbit have large ears? How has the camel adapted to the desert? What are some adaptations of marine organisms?

The Ecosystems HD app will be a treat for the curious learner.

Photos and videos describe the characteristics of the biomes and their inhabitants. The Did You Know section has "WOW" facts related to each biome. The text to speech function allows the text to be narrated.

The ecosystems matching game is a fun matching game for the various ecosystems and their inhabitants. The quiz is based on Bloom's taxonomy and is designed to test not only remembering and understanding but also applying, evaluating, and analyzing the concepts.

The content correlates to State Science Standards in the USA.

Features:

- Curated photos and videos with descriptive text with free periodic refresh of photos and videos.

- Did You Know section with WOW facts about each topic.

- Easy, Intermediate and Advanced level questions based on Bloom's Taxonomy to test knowledge about the various topics.

- Fun, matching game refreshed periodically with new content.


*****

 For more information on news and updates, like us on Facebook and follow us on Twitter @SproutLabs.

*****

For feature requests, feedback or support, send email to support@sproutlabs.net
app.curriculum:
Ecosystems App

Correlation to California State Science Standards

Grade K
*******
Life Sciences:
	2a – The student will describe similarities and differences in the appearance and behavior of insects.
	2c – The student will identify major structures of common animals.

Grade 1
*******
Life Sciences:
	2a – The student knows plants and animals inhabit different kinds of environments and have external features that help them thrive in different kinds of places.
	2b – The student knows that animals need food.
	2c – The student knows animals use plants for food.
	2d – The student knows how to infer what animals eat from the shape of their teeth.

Grade 2
*******
Life Sciences:
	2a – The student knows organisms reproduce offspring of their own kind and that the offspring resemble the parents and each other.
	2b – The student knows the sequential stages of life cycle of animals.
	2c – The student knows many characteristics of organisms are inherited from parents.

Grade 3
*******
Life Sciences:
	2a – The student knows animals have structures that serve different functions in growth, survival, and reproduction.
	2d – The student knows when the environment changes, some animals survive while others die or move to new locations.

_______

introTexts.item: Rocks, Every living thing, plant or animal, has a home. It's natural home is called its habitat.
Rocks, These living things or biotic components, live in balance and interact with each other and with the non-living or abiotic components.
Rocks, Abiotic components include light, air, water, soil and temperature. Together with the biotic components, they make up an ecosystem.
Rocks, A biome is a large region that has plants, animals, and other living things that have adapted to the environmental conditions.
Rocks, A biome can have many different ecosystems.
Rocks, Plants and animals survive in their environment because of how they behave and how they are created. This is called adaptation.
Rocks, When the environment changes too quickly for living things to adapt, they can die, and entire species may become extinct.
Rocks, Thus, protecting the earth’s biomes, ecosystems, and habitats is very important!
Rocks, Go ahead and start exploring the major biomes and ecosystems of the world!

mainText.mainText:
What is a rock? Rocks are naturally occurring solid combinations of minerals and sometimes other materials too. The common rock granite is made of the minerals quartz, feldspar and biotite. When only one mineral is present, the object is a mineral, not rock. 
 Scientists classify rocks into three categories: igneous, sedimentary, and metamorphic. These are all part of the rock cycle. 
 Igneous rocks begin deep in the Earth, which contains solid and molten materials such as silicon, magnesium and iron. Magma bursts through the Earth's surface via volcanoes and cracks in the Earth's crust. At the surface it's called lava. Lava hardens to become new crust. 
 Rocks are exposed to ocean waves and weather. They slowly break down into pebbles and sand. Sedimentary rocks are made of the resulting sand and mud, material from plants and animals, and minerals left over when liquid evaporates. These all compact and harden to become rock. 
 Metamorphic rocks are made when rocks experience new temperature and pressure conditions. For example, contact with magma could cause rock to liquefy and then recrystallize into a different type of rock. 
 Scientists believe that humans have been using rocks for about 3.5 million years. Stone arrowheads were among our first tools. Today we mine rocks for use in roads, statues, buildings, chalkboards, jewelry, cosmetics and many other items.

item.name: Grassland-P5.png
item.title: Fertile grasslands are used for agriculture

item.name: Grassland-P6.png
item.title: New Zealand farm on a grassland

item.name: Grassland-P8.png
item.title: Camouflaged giraffe in the African Bush

item.text: Petrology is the study of the origin and composition of rocks.
Geology is the study of the Earth, rocks and the rock cycle.
A grain of sand is like a tiny rock! Look at one under a microscope.
Some rocks contain mineralites in addition to minerals. Glass is a mineralite.
Glass is made from superheated sand.
Igneous means fire in Latin. Igneous rocks come from magma.
When molten material cools inside the Earth's crust, intrusive rock is formed.
When lava cools outside the Earth's crust, extrusive rock is formed.
The Earth's outer rocky layer is called the lithosphere. It includes oceanic crust and continental crust.
Basalt is the most common rock on Earth. Much of the ocean's crust is basalt.
The Earth's continental crust is mainly andesite rock.
Marble is a metamorphic rock. It is usually made from limestone.
At least 300 degrees Fahrenheit (150 Celsius) are needed to cause metamorphic changes.
The Taj Mahal is made entirely of marble.
Geodes are ordinary-looking igneous or sedimentary rocks on the outside but contain beautiful crystals on the inside.
Meteorites, or rocks from outer space, help scientists learn about our solar system
One of the oldest rocks on Earth was brought from the Moon. Scientists believe it's about 4.5 billion years old.
The Himalayans are among the world’s youngest mountains. Scientists estimate that they formed 30 million years ago.
To estimate the age of a sedimentary rock, scientists consider its thickness, its mineral layers, and the plant and animal remains it may contain.
Mountains form when enormous pieces of the Earth's crust collide and bunch up.

item.title: The Life cycle of a Butterfly
Butterfly laying eggs in a garden
Grassland
item.description: Grasslands have mostly grasses and non-woody plants instead of shrubs and trees

item.title: Savanna
item.description: The Savanna of Africa is a tropical grassland with shrubs and some trees

item.title: Steppes
item.description: The Steppes of Eurasia are temperate grasslands and have a growing season and cold winters

item.title: Grassland soil
item.description: Grasslands have some of the worlds richest loam soil. The rich soil is ideal for farming and grazing

item.title: Pampas grass
item.description: The Pampas grass has deep roots to find water and can grow in almost any habitat

item.title: Baobab
item.description: The baobab tree uses its stems like a funnel to collect water

item.title: Elephants
item.description: Elephants in the savanna use camouflage to protect them from predators

item.title: Kudu
item.description: The grasslands vegetation provides shelter and camouflage for antelopes like the kudu

item.title: Springbok
item.description: Springboks can jump 13 feet high and long jump to 50 feet to escape from predators

item.title: Lioness
item.description: Predators in the grasslands also use camouflage to help them when hunting

item.title: Wildebeest
item.description: Animals like the wildebeest migrate large distances to find water during the dry season

item.title: Prairie dogs
item.description: Prairie dogs get their water from the plants and hibernate in the burrows during winter

item.title: Bird migration
item.description: Birds migrate to warmer climates during the cold winter

item.title: Bison
item.description: The American bison has thick fur that keeps it warm in winter and can be shed in summer to cool the animal

item.title: Vultures
item.description: Vultures have keen eyesight and strong beaks and help clean up the carcass of dead animals

item.title: Kangaroo
item.description: Kangaroos can travel long distances by hopping. They have four pairs of chewing teeth to eat the grasses

item.title: Fires
item.description: Natural causes like fires and human activities can impact and alter grassland ecosystems

item.title: Humans
item.description: Human activities can have a lasting impact on the ecosystem in the grasslands

item.question: For an object to be a rock in geologists' terms, what must it contain?
Creating sedimentary rocks primarily involves _________________.
Which rock type is most directly associated with molten (melted) material?
Which rocks are especially common in riverbeds?
Creating metamorphic rocks primarily involves _________________.

choice.answer: The compaction of sand and organic material

item.question: Judging from its name, sandstone is most likely ________.

Which rock would be most likely to contain glass?
Which of the following is true?
Which statement is true?

choice.answer: Oceanic crust is older than continental crust
Sedimentary rocks are not placed under pressure

item.question: To make a mountain, what must occur?
Oceanic crust is typically made through ________.
How would intrusive rock most likely reach the Earth's surface?

choice.answer: By filling cracks in the sea floor

item.question: If a planet did not have much weather, which rock type would take extra-long to form?

topic.name: desert
topic.mainText:
What is a mineral? Minerals such as gold, calcium and sodium are the building blocks of rocks. They are inorganic. That is, although rocks may contain matter from plants and animals, minerals do not. Minerals are purely chemical. They are typically solid at room temperature. 
 Minerals are made of the elements listed on the Periodic Table. Minerals may consist of just one element, such as gold, or they can be combinations of elements. Quartz, for example, is made of silicon and oxygen. 
 Plants and animals must adapt to be able to survive the desert’s tough conditions. Desert plants like cactus have thick and fleshy stems to store water. They also have spiny leaves to prevent loss of water through transpiration, which is similar to sweating. 
 Scientists classify minerals in several ways. Some categories are color, luster, hardness, specific gravity, and cleavage or how the mineral breaks. 
 When you're identifying minerals, color is helpful but not enough. Many minerals are found in multiple colors. Also, minerals may be impure; extra chemicals can change their color. Diamonds are made in every color of the rainbow. 
 “Luster” describes how a mineral reflects light. Some terms used to describe luster are brilliant, metallic, silky and dull. 
 Hardness is another way to classify a mineral. Hardness is measured by scratching a mineral. Diamonds are the hardest mineral on earth; they can scratch anything. 
 Specific gravity refers to density. Two mineral chunks of the same size can have different weights. Specific gravity can be measured by comparing a mineral's weight to an equal volume of water. 
 Cleavage and other characteristics of breakage help people classify minerals. For example, some crystals break with jagged edges. Others break along smooth planes. 
 People identify minerals in many other ways such as acid tests, radioactivity tests, and simply using their taste buds.

item.name: Desert-P7.png
item.title: Sahara desert sand dunes
item.attribution: Picture taken by Raul Santos de la Camara

item.text: Because elements can be combined in countless ways, scientists haven't set a limit for how many minerals exist.
The International Mineralogical Association recognizes approximately 4700 mineral species.
The most common mineral on Earth is quartz.
Amethyst, citrine and other types of quartz are the most common minerals used in jewelry.
The elements oxygen, silicon, aluminum, iron, magnesium, calcium, potassium, and sodium make up 98% of all minerals on Earth.
Mercury and water ice are exceptions to the rule that minerals are solid at room temperature.
The Mohs Hardness Scale is used to describe a mineral's hardness.
Because diamonds are so hard, they are useful in drill bits and other tools that cut.
Talc is the softest rock. It is used in body powder.
Crystals are minerals that have their atoms arranged in three-dimensional patterns.
Crystals are most likely to form when magma cools slowly and under great pressure.
When lava cools quickly, it's likely to form glassy rocks, not crystals.
Most of the Earth's crust is made of silicate minerals, which contain silicon and oxygen.
Eight important mineral groups are the silicates, native elements, sulfides, oxides, halides, carbonates, sulfates, and phosphates.
Native elements appear in nature uncombined with others. Examples are gold, silver and copper.
Halides are part halogen. Chloride and many other halides are salts.
Phosphates, which include the element phosphorus, are valued primarily as fertilizer and for detergents.
Heavy metal waste from phosphate mining has contaminated drinking water.
Sulfides, which combine sulfur with other minerals, may smell like rotten eggs. They are especially useful in medicine, art and agriculture.
Diamonds and pencil “lead” are made from the same element: carbon. The different look is explained by diamond's crystalline structure.

item.title: Newly hatched caterpillar eating its egg shells
Monarch caterpillar to Chrysalis time lapse
Sahara
item.description: The Sahara is the world's largest hot desert with temperatures reaching 122F or 50C

item.title: Antarctica
item.description: The Antarctic region is a polar or cold desert. It is the coldest and windiest place on earth

item.title: Atacama
item.description: The Atacama desert in Chile is a coastal desert that is considered the driest place on earth

item.title: Gobi Desert
item.description: The Gobi desert in Mongolia, a semi-arid desert, is in the rainshadow region of the Himalayas

item.title: Palm tree
item.description: Palm trees have deep fibrous roots to reach the water

item.title: Cacti
item.description: Cacti have long roots and use their thick, fleshy stems to store water

item.title: Cactus leaf
item.description: The cactus has spiny leaves to prevent loss of water through transpiration

item.title: Desert plants
item.description: Drought tolerant plants reduce their metabolism during dry seasons and resume growth after rains

item.title: Mulga
item.description: The Australian mulga tree has leaves that grow in the shape of funnels and direct rainwater to the roots

item.title: Acacia
item.description: The whitethorn acacia loses its leaves during severe droughts and has thorns to keep animals away

item.title: Camel
item.description: Camels have a hump to store fat that can be metabolized for energy when needed

item.title: Camel eyes
item.description: Camels have two rows of long eyelashes and nostrils that can be closed to keep the sand out

item.title: Camel legs
item.description: Camels have two toes on each foot and a pad that connects them and helps spread the weight so that they can walk on sand

item.title: Jackrabbit
item.description: The large ears of a jackrabbit with a network of blood vessels help dissipate heat when resting in the shade

item.title: Kangaroo rat
item.description: The kangaroo rat gets its water from the food it eats

item.title: Desert Tortoise
item.description: Desert tortoises stay cool by burrowing into the ground. They can live without water for a year

item.title: Thorny Devil Lizard
item.description: The thorny devil lizard's body is made of ridges that allow it to collect water from any part of the body and send it to its mouth

item.title: San people
item.description: The San people create sip wells to get water from the sand and eat animals and plants found in the Kalahari

choice.answer: Diurnal or active during the day

item.question: How do some mammals keep cool in the desert?

choice.answer: It helps the camel stay cool

choice.answer: They have no plants or animals

item.question: Some animals have adapted by not needing water to survive. How do they get the water?
Very often frost and snow can be seen on the dunes of Gobi desert. What type of desert is it
When plants and animals evolve to live in their habitat what is it called?
If a camel goes long enough without food, what will happen to its hump?

choice.answer: It will split into two humps

item.question: If the amount of rainfall increased what biome would the desert become?

choice.answer: Depletion or loss of water resources

topic.name: forest
topic.mainText:
Forests occupy about one third of Earth’s land area. There are three types of forests: tropical forests that occur near the equator, temperate forests that occur between the tropics and polar regions in both hemispheres, and the boreal forests or Taiga that are found between the temperate forest and tundra in the northern hemisphere. 
 Tropical rainforests have a lot of rainfall, and remain hot and humid throughout the year. Temperate forests have moderate climate and four seasons with a distinct winter. The Taiga (Russian word for forest) has short summers and long, severe winters. 
 Rainforest trees have thin barks and drip tip leaves to let rainwater runoff quickly. Trees also have buttress roots, prop roots, and stilt roots to provide support. Epiphytes (plants that grow on other plants) and lianas (climbing woody vines) are found in the rainforest. 
 Plants in the temperate forest have thick barks to prevent moisture loss. Temperate forests have coniferous (evergreen trees like pine, fir, cedar), deciduous (trees lose leaves in the fall and grow back in summer like maple, chestnut, oak) or broad leaved evergreens (like eucalyptus, holly, tea). Needle leaves of the conifers reduce evaporation during winter. Besides evergreen trees with needle leaves, lichens and mosses survive in the taiga. 
 Forest animals adapt to the weather in their forest and to the food that is available. Animals in the rainforest have adapted to living in trees. They also have bright colors and patterns, make loud sounds, and eat mostly fruits. In temperate forests, animals survive the cold winters by hibernating or migrating to warmer regions in the winter and returning in the summer.

item.name: Forests-P4.png
item.title: Deciduous trees lose leaves in the Fall

item.name: Forests-P5.png
item.title: Lichens and moss share a habitat

item.name: Forests-P7.png
item.title: Colorful macaws are found in the tropical rain forests

item.text: Rainforests have four layers: emergent, canopy, understory, and forest floor
More than 2,000 species of butterflies can be found in the rainforests of South America
Deciduous means falling off or out in a certain season
The tiny poison arrow frog may be pretty, but its bright colors act as a warning not to touch
Amazon rainforests produce about 40% of the world’s oxygen
Cool temperate rainforests are also called Moss Forests
Sloths move so slowly in the rainforests that algae are able to grow in their fur
One out of four ingredients in medicines comes from rainforests
Bats pollinate bananas and mangoes
30 million species of plants and animals live in tropical rainforests
In tropical countries, only 1 tree is planted for every 10 trees cut. About 2000 trees are cut per minute
Fall colors are due to plants withdrawing chlorophyll from their leaves during shortening days of fall
Temperate deciduous forests have fertile soil unlike the Taiga
The Taiga represents 29% of the world’s forests
The Taigana (taiga men) or Tsaatan are nomads of Mongolia supporting themselves on reindeer rearing
Drunken or tilted trees are found in the Taiga and are formed due to frost heaving or raising of the soil due to ice underneath
Animals in a deciduous forest are camouflaged to look like the ground of the forest
80% of all insect species live in the tropical rainforest
The taiga has the fewest animal and plants species of all biomes
A cloud forest or fog forest is a tropical forest that has a persistent mist or cloud

item.title: Monarch caterpillar turning into a cocoon
Tropical rainforest
item.description: Tropical rainforests get a lot of rainfall and remain hot and have thick, dense vegetation

item.title: Emergent layer
item.description: The tall trees that rise above the rainforest canopy make up the emergent layer.The canopy forms a roof over the understory and the forest floor layers

item.title: Epiphyte
item.description: Epiphytes are plants that grow on other plants. They are not parasites, but use the host plant for support

item.title: Buttress roots
item.description: Buttress or stilt or prop roots are large roots on the side of a tree with shallow roots

item.title: Drip tip leaves
item.description: Due to the heavy rainfall, plants have developed drip tip leaves to prevent growth of parasitic fungi

item.title: Howler monkey
item.description: Howler monkeys feed on leaves and fresh fruits found in the canopy layer. They use their loud howls to communicate and have a long tail that they keep wrapped around a branch even when walking

item.title: Scarlet macaw
item.description: Scarlet macaws have strong beaks to break the hard nuts found in the rainforest. They also use their beaks to dig for insects and can use them to pinch predators

item.title: Temperate forest
item.description: Temperate forests have moderate climate and have either coniferous, or deciduous, or broad leaved evergreen trees

item.title: Fall colors
item.description: As days get shorter in fall, deciduous trees begin withdrawing chlorophyll from the leaves to prepare for winter, creating the orange and yellow fall colors

item.title: Deciduous in winter
item.description: A deciduous, temperate forest in winter after the trees have shed all their leaves

item.title: Bird migration
item.description: 60-70 percent of the birds in the temperate rainforest migrate to the tropics during the cold, winter months

item.title: Monarch butterfly
item.description: Insects like the Monarch butterfly migrate from Canada starting in August and spend the winters in parts of Mexico or California before returning in spring

item.title: Taiga
item.description: Taiga forests have coniferous evergreens trees. Taiga trees have shallow roots and most plants are small and grow closer to the ground

item.title: Taiga plants
item.description: The poor soil of the taiga prevents the growth of large trees

item.title: Taiga winter
item.description: Winters are extremely cold and last for 5-7 months

item.title: Lynx
item.description: The lynx is well adapted for the taiga. It has a thick, furry coat with fur covered pads. The paws are wide and allow it to walk on the snow

item.title: Caribou
item.description: Caribous have small tails and short ears to reduce heat loss. Their legs are well suited for plodding through deep snow and for swimming. They have two layers of fur for keeping warm

item.title: Grizzly bear
item.description: Grizzly bears survive the cold winters by hibernating. They spend the fall season eating a lot of food to store energy. They are omnivores and eat whatever is available

item.question: A coniferous forest has

choice.answer: Trees that have needles and cones

item.question: What do deciduous trees do in the cold season?
What is a rainforest?

choice.answer: A forest where there is no rain
A forest where there is lots of rain

item.question: How much of Earth's land area do forests occupy?
Forests found near the equator are called

choice.answer: Tropic of Cancer and Tropic of Capricorn

choice.answer: The soil lacks minerals and nutrients

choice.answer: Stay inside a burrow or den

choice.answer: It helps them find food easily
It provides camouflage and protects them from predators

item.question: Why is the taiga soil not fertile?

choice.answer: The falling leaves from the conifers make it acidic
Moss and lichen consume all the nutrients in the soil

hotspotsOnBackground.backgroundText: World Map showing all the major type of ecosystems

hotspot.title: Africa, Desert
hotspot.text:
Deserts are very dry or arid regions of the world that receive fewer than ten inches of rain a year. Some deserts don't receive rainfall for four, five, or even more years in a row!
 There are four kinds of deserts: subtropical or hot and dry deserts, semi-arid deserts, coastal deserts and polar or cold deserts. Both the Arctic and Antarctic regions are polar deserts. Semi-arid deserts like Patagonia and Gobi have dry summers and cold winters and are often in the rain shadow region of a mountain range. The subtropical deserts that most people think about are places like the Sahara and Kalahari deserts of Africa, while the Atacama and the Namib are examples of coastal deserts that have long warm summers and cool winters.
 Plants and animals must adapt to be able to survive the desert’s tough conditions. Desert plants like cactus have thick and fleshy stems to store water. They also have spiny leaves to prevent loss of water through transpiration, which is similar to sweating.
 Camels have a hump (or two if it is a Bactrian camel) to store fat, which can be metabolized for energy. This allows the camel to go without food or water for long periods of time. Camels also have broad, leathery pads at the bottom of their hooves which prevents them from sinking in the sand. Camels have two rows of long eyelashes and nostrils that can be closed to keep the sand out.
 Most desert animals are nocturnal. They stay cool, hiding during daytime, and come out at night.
